brief_summary.textblock:
Orthostatic hypotension (OH) is defined as a fall in blood pressure when standing. Several
      different underlying diseases, conditions, or combinations of medicines may contribute to
      OH; therefore the cause of the condition varies among individuals. Some studies have shown
      that OH is associated with an increase in the rate of death, but it is not clear what role
      OH plays in increased morbidity. By studying what the prevalence of OH is in a generalized
      veteran population we expect increase clinical awareness of the degree of the problem so
      that patient care might be improved.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Veterans

          -  Between the ages of 18 and 89

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Current illness/infection

          -  Pregnant

study_pop.textblock:
Any able-bodied veteran (able to independently stand for 10 minutes) that presents for a
        routine clinical visit or a neurological clinic visit at the James J. Peters VA Medical
        Center and does not have an acute illness or infection is eligible to participate in the
        study.

clinical_study.official_title: The Incidence of Orthostatic Hypotension Among Veterans

primary_outcome.description: Change in blood pressure between Evaluation #1 and Evaluation #2.
primary_outcome.measure: Change in blood pressure from supine to standing.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.source: James J. Peters Veterans Affairs Medical Center

lead_sponsor.agency: James J. Peters Veterans Affairs Medical Center

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Cohort, Time Perspective: Retrospective
